description: doc: Getting Started with Go, App Engine and Google+ API article.

messages.text:
Independently of the question of whether this should be in the Go repository (others need to decide this), here are some comments on the language. http://codereview.appspot.com/5853047/diff/6019/doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html File doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html (right): http://codereview.appspot.com/5853047/diff/6019/doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html#newcode2 doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html:2: "Title": "Getting Start with Go, App Engine and Google+ API", Getting started with Go, App Engine and the Google+ API http://codereview.appspot.com/5853047/diff/6019/doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html#newcode15 doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html:15:
  • Call Google+ API from a Go program
    • the Google+ API http://codereview.appspot.com/5853047/diff/6019/doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html#newcode23 doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html:23:

    Before You Start

    Use a heading style here (h2?). http://codereview.appspot.com/5853047/diff/6019/doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html#newcode34 doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html:34: First, we need to create the skeleton for our new App Engine application. At the end of this section, our development environment should look like this: Decide on a person, either "you" or "we". This applies to all of the text. http://codereview.appspot.com/5853047/diff/6019/doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html#newcode46 doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html:46:
  • Create a new directory named go-plus-appengine in your home directory. This directory will contains your App Engine application files.
    • will contain http://codereview.appspot.com/5853047/diff/6019/doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html#newcode64 doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html:64:

    Hello Google+

    heading http://codereview.appspot.com/5853047/diff/6019/doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html#newcode69 doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html:69:
  • In go-plus-appengine directory, download go-api-go-client and its dependencies using mercurial like so: s,In,In the, s,like so,like this, http://codereview.appspot.com/5853047/diff/6019/doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html#newcode75 doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html:75: hg clone https://code.google.com/p/google-api-go-client Use "go get". http://codereview.appspot.com/5853047/diff/6019/doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html#newcode79 doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html:79: curl http://codereview.appspot.com/download/issue5448092_1003.diff | patch -p0 What? http://codereview.appspot.com/5853047/diff/6019/doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html#newcode85 doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html:85:
  • In goplus directory create a file named config.go with the following content, and replace YOUR_API_KEY with the api key you just generated. s,In,In the, s/directory/directory,/ http://codereview.appspot.com/5853047/diff/6019/doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html#newcode89 doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html:89:
  • In goplus directory create a file named gopher.go with the following content. s,In,In the, http://codereview.appspot.com/5853047/diff/6019/doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html#newcode139 doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html:139:
  • Search the Google+ stream in background using Task Queue or Cron, persist the result in the Datastore, and memcache the most recent image URL.
    • s,in,in the,

Hello golang-dev@googlegroups.com (cc: golang-dev@googlegroups.com),

I'd like you to review this change to
http://code.google.com/p/go

http://codereview.appspot.com/5853047/diff/2002/doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html File doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html (right): http://codereview.appspot.com/5853047/diff/2002/doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html#newcode2 doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html:2: "Title": "Getting Start with Go, App Engine and Google+ API", We need a snappier title. "Go plus App Engine" is nice. http://codereview.appspot.com/5853047/diff/2002/doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html#newcode7 doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html:7: This article is an introduction to writing web applications that call Google APIs using the Go programming language. It shows you how to build a simple App Engine web application using Go. This app as a rather silly purpose: displaying the most recent "Gopher" image from the Google+ public stream. It's not our policy, but I would prefer that these lines were wrapped at 80 columns (or at least <120 columns) so they're more readable in codereview. http://codereview.appspot.com/5853047/diff/2002/doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html#newcode7 doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html:7: This article is an introduction to writing web applications that call Google APIs using the Go programming language. It shows you how to build a simple App Engine web application using Go. This app as a rather silly purpose: displaying the most recent "Gopher" image from the Google+ public stream. s/as a/has a/ s/rather silly/simple/ You've got a redirect in the URL. It should be /doc/go_faq/#... http://codereview.appspot.com/5853047/diff/2002/doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html#newcode14 doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html:14:
  • Build a skeleton for a Go App Engine web application
    • , http://codereview.appspot.com/5853047/diff/2002/doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html#newcode15 doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html:15:
  • Call Google+ API from a Go program
    • , and http://codereview.appspot.com/5853047/diff/2002/doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html#newcode16 doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html:16:
  • Deploy your web application to App Engine
    • . http://codereview.appspot.com/5853047/diff/2002/doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html#newcode20 doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html:20: The source code for this tutorial is available in Go documentation directory. available in the /doc/articles/goplus/ directory of the Go distribution. (and move the code there) http://codereview.appspot.com/5853047/diff/2002/doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html#newcode26 doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html:26:
  • Download Google App Engine SDK for Go1
    • s/for Go1// add http://codereview.appspot.com/5853047/diff/2002/doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html#newcode26 doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html:26:
  • Download Google App Engine SDK for Go1
  • Install the App Engine SDK:
    • Download...
    • Extract...
    • http://codereview.appspot.com/5853047/diff/2002/doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html#newcode27 doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html:27:
  • Extract the sdk zip file in your home directory, this will create a new directory named google_appengine
    • s/sdk/SDK/ http://codereview.appspot.com/5853047/diff/2002/doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html#newcode31 doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html:31: Hello Go on App Engine

    http://codereview.appspot.com/5853047/diff/2002/doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html#newcode46 doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html:46:
  • Create a new directory named go-plus-appengine in your home directory. This directory will contains your App Engine application files.
    • s/contains/contain/ http://codereview.appspot.com/5853047/diff/2002/doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html#newcode47 doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html:47:
  • Inside your go-plus-appengine directory, create a new file named app.yaml with the following content. This file contains your App Engine application configuration. s/your/the/ (only first occurrence) http://codereview.appspot.com/5853047/diff/2002/doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html#newcode47 doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html:47:
  • Inside your go-plus-appengine directory, create a new file named app.yaml with the following content. This file contains your App Engine application configuration. s/new // http://codereview.appspot.com/5853047/diff/2002/doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html#newcode50 doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html:50:
  • Next, create a directory called goplus inside your go-plus-appengine directory. This goplus directory will contain your Go code.
    • s/your/the/ (only first occurrence) http://codereview.appspot.com/5853047/diff/2002/doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html#newcode51 doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html:51:
  • Inside the goplus directory, create a new file named hello.go with the following content: s/new // http://codereview.appspot.com/5853047/diff/2002/doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html#newcode54 doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html:54:
  • Start the development server by running dev_appserver.py (located in the the SDK directory) on the command line, with the directory of your application as its first argument. dev_appserver.py s/SDK/google_appengine/ http://codereview.appspot.com/5853047/diff/2002/doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html#newcode56 doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html:56: /path/to/google_appengine/dev_appserver.py go-plus-appengine/ s/\/$// http://codereview.appspot.com/5853047/diff/2002/doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html#newcode62 doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html:62: You should see: Hello Gopher!

    http://codereview.appspot.com/5853047/diff/2002/doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html#newcode66 doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html:66:

    Now that we've created our Go application on App Engine, let's extend it to make API calls to the Google+ API. To do so, we first need to import the Google API Client Library for Go and its dependencies. Then we'll search the public stream for an activity with a Gopher photo attached to it.

    s/To do so, we first need to/First we must/ s/we'll/we will use it to/ s/stream/Google+ stream/ s/an activity .+./Gopher photos./ http://codereview.appspot.com/5853047/diff/2002/doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html#newcode68 doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html:68:
      We need a paragraph here to describe what the two libraries are, and where they will be placed. Like: The Google API Client Libraries are in a repository at code.google.com/p/google-api-go-client. We will use this path as the package's import path, so when we download the package we must place it in that same path relative to the go-plus-appengine directory. The google-api-go-client packages use OAuth to make authenticated HTTP requests, so we must also install the "goauth2" package located at code.google.com/p/goauth2. When we are done, the package tree will look like this: 
      google_appengine/
go-plus-appengine/
    app.yaml
    code.google.com/p/goauth2
    code.google.com/p/google-api-go-client 
    goplus/
        hello.go
      http://codereview.appspot.com/5853047/diff/2002/doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html#newcode69 doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html:69:
    1. In go-plus-appengine directory, download go-api-go-client and its dependencies using mercurial like so: s/In/From the/ s/ using mercurial like so// http://codereview.appspot.com/5853047/diff/2002/doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html#newcode72 doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html:72: cd /path/to/go-plus-appengine drop the indent http://codereview.appspot.com/5853047/diff/2002/doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html#newcode89 doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html:89:
    2. In goplus directory create a file named gopher.go with the following content. s/.$/:/ http://codereview.appspot.com/5853047/diff/2002/doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html#newcode94 doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html:94: The gopher function is doing a couple of things here: A "couple" means two. The gopher function does several things: http://codereview.appspot.com/5853047/diff/2002/doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html#newcode97 doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html:97:
    3. Initializes the plus service with our developer key
      4. Set up a plus service using the developer key, Call the Search method with the keyword "gopher", Scan the results, looking for a photo attachment, and Redirect the client to the first image URL found. http://codereview.appspot.com/5853047/diff/2002/doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html#newcode103 doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html:103:

      The google-api-go-client provides a set of Go types with methods that allow us to interact with the Google+ API as we would with any native Go package. These types are regenerated from the Google+ API metadata on each google-api-go-client release.

      s/that allow us to interact/for interacting/ s/Go // s_regenerated.$_generated automatically using the Google APIs Discovery Service._ http://codereview.appspot.com/5853047/diff/2002/doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html#newcode106 doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html:106:
    4. Open http://localhost:8080/gopher in your browser.
      5. s/Open/Visit/ http://codereview.appspot.com/5853047/diff/2002/doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html#newcode111 doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html:111: Deploy to App Engine

      http://codereview.appspot.com/5853047/diff/2002/doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html#newcode116 doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html:116:

    5. Go to appengine.google.com.
      6. (you will need to be logged into your Google Account) http://codereview.appspot.com/5853047/diff/2002/doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html#newcode119 doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html:119:
    6. Replace application: goplus with the application id you chose. s/chose/chose earlier/ http://codereview.appspot.com/5853047/diff/2002/doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html#newcode122 doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html:122:
    7. Deploy your application by running appcfg.py (located in the the SDK directory) with the command update and your application directory as the last argument. s_with.+_with the update command._ http://codereview.appspot.com/5853047/diff/2002/doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html#newcode123 doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html:123: 
      appcfg.py update go-plus-appengine/
      s/\/// http://codereview.appspot.com/5853047/diff/2002/doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html#newcode125 doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html:125:
    8. Load http://yourapplicationid.appspot.com/gopher you should see a fresh picture of a Gopher every time someone post one on Google+ public stream.
      9. s/Load/visit/ s/yourapplicationid/YOUR_APP_ID/ wrap url in http://codereview.appspot.com/5853047/diff/2002/doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html#newcode125 doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html:125:
    9. Load http://yourapplicationid.appspot.com/gopher you should see a fresh picture of a Gopher every time someone post one on Google+ public stream.
      10. s/every time/whenever/ s/post/posts/ s/on/to the/ http://codereview.appspot.com/5853047/diff/2002/doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html#newcode128 doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html:128: Your friends can easily embed a gopher in their webpages using this HTML snippet. s/Your friends/Now you or your friends/ http://codereview.appspot.com/5853047/diff/2002/doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html#newcode130 doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html:130: 
      <img src="yourapplicationid.appspot.com/gopher">
      s/yourapplicationid/YOUR_APP_ID/ http://codereview.appspot.com/5853047/diff/2002/doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html#newcode138 doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html:138:
    10. Allow user to search for arbitrary images (not only Gopher).
      11. s/only/just/ s/Gopher/"gopher"/ http://codereview.appspot.com/5853047/diff/2002/doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html#newcode139 doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html:139:
    11. Search the Google+ stream in background using Task Queue or Cron, persist the result in the Datastore, and memcache the most recent image URL.
      12. Search the Google+ stream in the background using Task Queues or the Cron service. Store the results in the datastore and use memcache to cache the most recent image URL. http://codereview.appspot.com/5853047/diff/2002/doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html#newcode144 doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html:144: Make sure to check the Google+ Go Starter Project, a more advanced sample that you can experiment with, that covers all the functions of the Google+ API. s/that you can experiment with, // http://codereview.appspot.com/5853047/diff/2002/doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html#newcode144 doc/articles/go_plus_appengine.html:144: Make sure to check the Google+ Go Starter Project, a more advanced sample that you can experiment with, that covers all the functions of the Google+ API. s/Make/Be/ s/check/check out/ http://codereview.appspot.com/5853047/diff/6019/doc/progs/go-plus-appengine/goplus/gopher.go File doc/progs/go-plus-appengine/goplus/gopher.go (right): http://codereview.appspot.com/5853047/diff/6019/doc/progs/go-plus-appengine/goplus/gopher.go#newcode5 doc/progs/go-plus-appengine/goplus/gopher.go:5: // Import google api go client library throughout the file, make the comments sentences. // Import the Google API Go Client library. http://codereview.appspot.com/5853047/diff/6019/doc/progs/go-plus-appengine/goplus/gopher.go#newcode9 doc/progs/go-plus-appengine/goplus/gopher.go:9: // Import appengine urlfetch package, that is needed to make http call to the api s/that .+$/to make API calls/

Thanks a lot for the extensive review. Global changes: replaced 'we' occurence by 'you', h2 for title, and 80 columns for long

You surely know App Engine better than me, but this seems very strange. Can't you make a GOPATH entry?

On 2012/03/26 17:14:40, bsiegert wrote:
> LGTM
>

> On 2012/03/26 14:25:06, proppy wrote:
> > On 2012/03/19 09:29:14, bsiegert wrote:
> > > Use "go get".
> > 
> > Go get won't work, because we need to copy the file to the app engine app
> > directory.
> 
> You surely know App Engine better than me, but this seems very strange. Can't
> you make a GOPATH entry?

AFAIK Go still rely on App Engine tooling (appcfg.py) to deploy application.

While this would be a nice feature, the current tooling is not aware of GOPATH.

You still have to bundle all your dependencies in your application directory before deploying it.
